I just wanted to comment on the elitism discussion that has been part of =
the broader discussion of multiagent HyperNEAT.

In my NEAT implementation,=
 elitism is not a percentage.  Rather, the champion of each species is copi=
ed into the next generation as long as the species is at least some minimal=
 size (otherwise the species would never change).  Jason's SmallestSpeciesS=
izeWithElitism variable is about that.

Keeping the champion of each specie=
s makes sense because it means the species will all remember their best sol=
ution yet, rather than only the champion of the top species.  I'm not sure =
what exactly the elitism percentage means in some other systems like SharpN=
EAT.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> =
> Hi Jeff,
> > 
> > Thanks for your interest in our paper.
> 
> Hi David. N=
o problem. Thanks for the answers.
> 
> > In response to comments 1-3, we'v=
e actually run several preliminary
> > experiments with the intent of answe=
ring the questions you've asked.  We hope
> > to have a publication with fo=
rmal results based on those experiments soon.  In
> > general though, we do=
 feel that this approach is superior to the one discussed
> > in the previo=
us multiagent HyperNEAT paper and would recommend anyone who
> > wants to w=
ork with multiagent HyperNEAT to use the z-based substrate.
> 
> Cool. I lo=
ok forward to seeing the paper.
> 
> > 4.  Way back when I first converted =
SharpNEAT to HyperSharpNEAT I tried a
> > number of values and found that t=
here wasn't a large difference between them,
> > although 20% seemed to be =
slightly better.  For any new domains I'll try a few
> > values to see if t=
hey make any difference, but I haven't found any where the
> > elitism valu=
e made a significant difference.
> > 
> > I will say that I've never tried =
just saving the best organism.  One reason is
> > that the SharpNEAT specia=
tion code isn't really designed to only save one
> > genome.  The other is =
that I think saving at least the best genomes in your
> > best species woul=
d help prevent promising species from accidentally dying off
> > too early.=
  On the other hand, I know you have several successful HyperNEAT
> > exper=
iments, so I guess I'll turn the question back on you: Have you found
> > s=
aving just the best genome to generally be better than saving more?  I'm
> =
> certainly willing to give it a try if you've seen much better results.
> =

> I have never changed these parameters. But now that we are discussing it=
 I
> am realizing I don't actually know how much elitism I am using. I thin=
k I am
> using the same parameters from Jason's experiments. I was focusing=
 on this
> parameter, which is why I said I keep only the best org:
> 
> Fo=
rceCopyGenerationChampion 1.0
> 
> But I now also see these parameters in m=
y experiment config files:
> 
> SmallestSpeciesSizeWithElitism 5.0
> Mutate=
SpeciesChampionProbability 0.0
> 
> How do I figure out my % elitism, so I =
know how my number compares to your
> 20%?  
> 
> > 5.  The answer to wheth=
er we renormalize the sheets or insert the new sheets
> > between the old i=
s technically both.  In general we renormalize, that is
> > however many ag=
ents there are, they are evenly spaced between -1 and 1.  While
> > it may =
seem like a good idea to leave the original sheets where they were and
> > =
insert the new ones among them, in most cases it is difficult to determine
=
> > where the new sheets should go.
> > 
> > For example, if there were 5 a=
gents located at z=3D{-1, -0.5, 0, 0.5, 1} and the
> > team needed to be sc=
aled to 7 agents, where should the two new agents go?
> > There are two age=
nts, but four spaces (-0.75, -0.25, 0.25, 0.75) to put them
> > and no real=
 reason to choose any of the spaces over the others.  By
> > redistributing=
 the agents evenly we eliminate such ad hoc decisions.  However,
> > if the=
 5 agent team were to be scaled up to 9 agents, they would be placed at
> >=
 z=3D{-1, -0.75, -0.5, -0.25, 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75,1}.  Thus, even though we'=
re
> > renormalizing, the placement works out the same as if we had inserte=
d the new
> > agents among the old.
> 
> That makes sense, and seems like t=
he right way to do it.
> 
> > 6.  The sign function simply returns the sign=
 of the node's activation: -1 if
> > the activation is negative, 0 if it is=
 0, and 1 if it is positive.
> >The reason 
> > for this function and the s=
tarting structure is to establish a team with
> > mirror symmetry i.e. the =
ANN of the agent at z=3D 1 is the horizontally flipped
> > version of the a=
gent at z=3D-1 and so on.  We found that team mirror symmetry
> > was benef=
icial in both domains that were tested in this paper, so it was
> > logical=
 to allow it to start with symmetry (which can be broken or ignored
> > wit=
h mutations).
> 
> Ok. I get it. Thanks for clarifying.
> 
> > I hope I've =
answered your questions,
> 
> You did. Thanks again for all the answers, an=
d congrats on the great work.
> 
> -Jeff
> 
> > David
> > 
> > 
> > --- In =
neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> Congrats on th=
is paper. It features a lot of nice results.
> >> 
> >> A few questions/com=
ments:
> >> 
> >> 1) The issue of interpolation is extremely interesting. I=
n this paper you
> >> explicitly discuss how it would be beneficial to add =
new agents, and have
> >> their roles be intermediate versions of other age=
nts (e.g., adding a 12th
> >> soccer player between the forwards and the mi=
dfielders would create a player
> >> that was a hybrid of the two roles). I=
t would also be cool to see if teams
> >> can gracefully re-divide the stra=
tegy-space when they lose agents. For
> >> example, in soccer/futbol, after=
 a few red cards are assigned, each player
> >> does not play the usual rol=
e that they would play on a team of 11, but
> >> instead re-divide the spac=
e up amongst the fewer players. For example, after
> >> the red cards their=
 may be a left and right forward instead of a left, right
> >> and center f=
orward. It would be cool to see if you can see such a result
> >> using you=
r method.
> >> 
> >> 2) You mention the benefits of interpolated roles, but=
 do you have any
> >> evidence that such interpolation is occurring? One co=
ol way to test this
> >> would be to compare two different treatments: T1) =
take your original N
> >> agents and multiply them to achieve the desired s=
caled-up number of agents
> >> (e.g., 9, 25, 100, 1000). If you start with =
10 agents, and scale to 1000,
> >> you thus get 100 identical copies of age=
nt 1, 100 identical copies of agent
> >> 2, etc. Compare the performance of=
 this treatment to T2) interpolate 1000
> >> agents into the z coordinate r=
ange, so you have 1000 slightly different
> >> agents. The difference in pe=
rformance between these treatments will help you
> >> figure out whether yo=
u are seeing a boost due to interpolation. If the
> >> performance increase=
 due to scaling is not different between T1 and T2, then
> >> you know your=
 performance boost was simply due to having more agents, not
> >> due to in=
terpolation (you note something similar when you say "adding more
> >> agen=
ts that all do the same thing will eventually cause a pile-up"...my
> >> su=
ggestion is a way to test this claim).
> >> 
> >> 3) Why do you feel this n=
ew technique is better than your old technique? Is
> >> it possible to comp=
are the two experimentally? Have you done so?
> >> 
> >> 4) I notice you me=
ntion that you use 20% elitism. I usually only save the
> >> best organism.=
 Have you found 20% to work a lot better, generally?
> >> 
> >> 5) When you=
 add new agents, do you leave the previous sheets in the same
> >> place, a=
nd interpolate new sheets between them, or do you renormalize all of
> >> t=
he sheets such that it may be the case that no new agent is in the exact z
=
> >> coordinate of one of the original agents? It might be interesting to t=
ry
> >> both and see which tends to work better.
> >> 
> >> 6) What is the =
'sign' function you mention in Figure 2? In general, I am
> >> having troub=
le figuring out what this means: "The starting structure of the
> >> initia=
l heterogeneous CPPN (Figure 2b) includes some additional structure to
> >>=
 start evolution with knowledge of mirrored team symmetry; in particular, t=
he
> >> sign function of z connected to multiplication operators on the x-a=
xis means
> >> that the CPPN knows which side of the team is which and can =
opt to reflect
> >> one side across the midline."
> >> 
> >> Congrats again=
 on this nice work.
> >> 
> >> Best regards,
> >> Jeff Clune
> >> 
> >> Dig=
ital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> >> jclune@
> >> www.msu.edu=
/~jclune
> >>

> =
>>> Subject: [neat] Multiagent HyperNEAT Revisited
> >>> 
> >>> Our 2008 GE=
CCO paper by David D'Ambrosio and myself introduced the idea that
> >>> a
>=
 >>> single HyperNEAT CPPN can encode a set of neural networks (instead of =
just
> >>> one) that represent a pattern of policies for an entire team.  S=
ince then a
> >>> few people have asked about the way we laid out the team =
on the substrate
> >>> and
> >>> whether alternatives might be better.
> >>=
> 
> >>> I am happy to announce, with my co-authors David D'Ambrosio, Joel =
Lehman,
> >>> and
> >>> Sebastian Risi, that we have extensively tested suc=
h an alternative
> >>> z-axis-based encoding and published the results to a=
ppear in AAMAS 2010,
> >>> available here:
> >>> 
> >>> http://eplex.cs.ucf=
.edu/publications/2010/dambrosio.aamas10.html
> >>> 
> >>> Direct Link: htt=
p://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/dambrosio_aamas10.pdf
> >>> 
> >>> We believe t=
his z-based substrate layout is superior to the previous one,
> >>> particu=
larly for scaling the size of the team, and should open up the field
> >>> =
of
> >>> multiagent learning further to HyperNEAT.  The paper also includes=
 the first
> >>> published results on scaling the size of the team without =
further training,
> >>> which works because HyperNEAT can interpolate new p=
olicies for ANNs inserted
> >>> along the z axis of the substrate.
> >>> 
>=
 >>> Videos that accompany the paper are here:
> >>> http://eplex.cs.ucf.ed=
u/mahnaamas2010.html
> >>> 
> >>> ken
> >>>
